discourse_list.title: Things we really want smart contracts to implement (or not)

content.content: I saw a couple of Tweets from Dan Robinson and thought it was a good idea to try to get people to contribute more. This is “best practices coming from the frustrations of developers and data consumers”. Smart contract systems which make building a local state / database possible from events.   twitter.com    Dan Robinson (danrobinson)  Another grumpy demand: it should always be possible to compute the current state of a contract from the list of past events for that contract.  (If all else fails this can be accomplished by just logging the state itself whenever it changes, like Uniswap v2 does w/ reserves.) https://t.co/zQ2eZ7Chd9Dan Robinson @danrobinsonBuilding a non-standard ERC-20 token (such as fee-on-transfer or inflationary/deflationary balances) is one of the nastiest things you can do to smart contract developers, wallet developers, and users  11:26 AM - 14 Dec 2020     9          2            Non-standard ERC-20 tokens (antipattern)   twitter.com    Dan Robinson (danrobinson)  Building a non-standard ERC-20 token (such as fee-on-transfer or inflationary/deflationary balances) is one of the nastiest things you can do to smart contract developers, wallet developers, and users  3:22 PM - 5 Aug 2020     86          6
content.GPT-summary: The post discusses best practices for smart contract systems, including the ability to build a local state/database from events and avoiding the creation of non-standard ERC-20 tokens. Dan Robinson's tweets are referenced as a source of frustration for developers and data consumers.
